Thomasma No. 8 Facility
Executive Summary

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES

The Thomasma No. 8 Facility is committed to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident protection, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of our processes.  Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  However, if a release does occur, trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release.

The Thomasma No. 8 Facility, located approximately 17 miles south of Mirando City in Zapata County, Texas, produces natural gas liquids from natural gas.  These natural gas liquids are comprised primarily of pentane, propane, butane, and heavier hydrocarbons, some of which are regulated flammable substances.

OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS RESULTS

There are no toxic chemicals stored at the Thomasma No. 8 Facility above the EPA Threshold Quantity.  The threshold quantity is the level set by the EPA for each toxic or flammable chemical which if stored at the site requires compliance with the EPA?s Risk Management Program (RMP) regulations.  Generally, if the amount of a substance stored on-site is less than the threshold quantity, there is little danger to the public.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

Because the process at the Thomasma No. 8 Facility which is regulated by the EPA RMP rule is not subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation, no additional steps for accidental release prevention are required.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no accidental releases at the Thomasma No. 8 Facility that have occurred in the past 5 years that have resulted in offsite effects.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATON

Emergency response procedures have been coordinated with the Zapata County Fire Department.  This provides a means of notifying the public of an incid

ent, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.

CONCLUSION

The Thomasma No. 8 Facility has a very safe operating history.  However, the facility continually looks for improvements, both to the process and to safety issues at the facility.  Our company is very active in promoting coordination between the local emergency response agencies and our facility personnel.  Ongoing communication between our facility and the emergency responders is a integral part of our operations.
